Promotional effects of Nb on selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 over Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) oxides catalysts Sher Ali Yushi Li Tianrui Zhang Syed ul Hasnain Bakhtiar Xuesong Leng Zhibin Li Fulong Yuan Xiaoyu Niu ⁎ Yujun Zhu ⁎ Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (Heilongjiang University), Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Materials, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, 150080, PR China Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (Heilongjiang University) Ministry of Education School of Chemistry and Materials Heilongjiang University Harbin 150080 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 oxides exhibited above 90% NO conversion in the range of 180–400 °C, together with near 100% N2 selectivity and remarkable SO2/H2O resistance due to the strong interaction among Nb, Fe and Ce oxides. Citric acid method was employed to prepare a series of Nb-promoted Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) oxides for selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) of NO process. The structure, redox ability and reactivity of NH3 and absorbed NO species on the catalysts were explored by using various characterization techniques such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature program reduction with H2 (H2-TPR), temperature program desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD), temperature program desorption of NO (NO-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and in situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS). It was found that the Nb promoted Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) oxides catalysts showed outstanding NH3-SCR of NO activity, excellent N2 selectivity and remarkable SO2/H2O resistance, meanwhile, Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 exhibited above 90% NO conversion in the range of 180–400 °C, together with near 100% N2 selectivity. The characterization results point out that the excellent catalytic performance of Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 can be ascribed to the strong interaction among Nb, Fe and Ce oxides. The strong interaction not only increases the BET surface area and redox ability of the catalyst, but also significantly improves the acid amount leading to the enhancement of the adsorption and activation of NH3, which is advantage of the reactivity of adsorbed nitrate together with the adsorbed NH3 species. Keywords Selective catalytic reduction NO NH3 Nb Fe and Ce oxides 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO, NO2 and N2O) are the major contributor to the air pollution, which is mainly emitted to the atmosphere through stationary resources like coal-fired power plants and mobile resources such as diesel engines [1–4]. At present time, the removal nitrogen oxides from the atmosphere become a challenging task worldwide. To get this task, different de-nitrification techniques are used including adsorption method, carbon reduction, selective non-catalytic reduction, pulse corona plasma, electron beam irradiation and selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) [3,5]. Recently the NH3-SCR has been known as the most effective, interesting, imperative, promising and commercial employed technique for NOx control [6–10]. Commercial V2O5-WO3(MoO3)-TiO2 catalysts have extensively used in electric plant [6,9,11]. However, certain factors constrain their usage for nonelectric plant, and still need to improve these limitations such as a narrow operating temperature window (300–400 °C), unselective oxidation of NH3 to produce N2O at high temperatures and toxicity of vanadium to the eco-environment and human health [12–14]. In addition, the temperature of exhaust smoke NO x emitted from various stationary resources such as industrial boiler, cement kiln, glass melting stove, coal power plant, cooker heater and combustion furnaces et al. is far lower than 300 °C [15,16]. The conventional V2O5-WO3(MoO3)-TiO2 catalysts are not efficient for above exhaust smoke NO x . Therefore, it is very important to develop new NH3-SCR catalysts with excellent low-temperature NO conversion, high N2 selectivity and a wide reaction temperature window. Many researchers have been found some transition metal oxides, such as Fe2O3, MnOx, CuO, CeO2 and a verity of mixed metal oxides, are active for NH3-SCR of NO [11,17]. Among them, iron-based catalysts, including Fe-zeolites [18], Fe(S)-Ti [19], Fe-Ti-V [20], Fe-Mn [21], Fe−Mn/Ti−Zr [22], Fe-Ti [13], Fe-V [23] and Fe-Ce oxides [24], exhibited promising low temperature NH3-SCR activity because of its outstanding reducibility and the presence of abundant amount of surface active mobile oxygen. However, certain disadvantages such as relatively low surface acidity, low N2 selectivity above 350 °C and poor SO2/H2O resistance etc. [24]. In order to overcome the shortcomings, many active ingredients such as Ti, V, and Mn were added to iron oxide, but the resultant catalysts did not exhibited satisfactory NH3-SCR activity. To improve the catalytic potential, the introduction of appropriate auxiliaries into the pure iron oxide catalyst system is very important [25]. Nowadays, ceria and ceria containing materials have been widely employed as catalysts because of its excellent oxygen storage- release capacity, non-toxicity, lower cost and excellent redox properties [26]. Based on these properties, many researcher develop Ce-based catalysts for NH3-SCR such as CeO2-WO3 [27], Ce-Al2O3 [28], TiO2/CeO2 [29], MnOx-CeO2 [30], CuO/Ti0.95Ce0.05O2 [31] and CeO2-V2O5-WO3/TiO2 etc. [32]. The above catalysts showed different SCR activities in different conditions, but commonly these catalysts suffer from rigorous deactivation by SO2 poisoning and insufficient activity at low temperature. According to literature [33], the introduction of Fe to Ce/TiO2 catalysts can improve the NH3-SCR activity about 25% at 200 °C. In order to improve the catalyst activity at low temperature, the ideas for the combination of Fe and Ce in one catalyst system are highly encouraged. In addition, recently the Nb-containing compounds were used in different reactions, such as the catalytic elimination of nitrogen oxides and catalytic hydrogenation of alkane [34]. The addition of Nb in some catalysts such as Ag-Nb2O5/Al2O3 [35] and V2O5-Nb2O5-Sb2O5/TiO2 [36] can enhance the NH3-SCR activity for removal of NO. Casapu et al. [37] reported that the introduction of Nb dramatically increased the NH3-SCR reactivity of MnOx-CeO2, and inhibited the unselective NH3 oxidation at high temperature. Moreover, the strong interaction between Nb and Mn can remarkably increase the catalytic active sites. According to the study of Qu et al. [37], the CeO2-Nb2O5 catalyst exhibited excellent NH3-SCR activity, furthermore it contained abundant surface absorbed oxygen due to the short-range activation effect of Ce to Nb species. Therefore, in the present work, through citric acid method a number of Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) oxides were prepared and were applied in the NH3-SCR process. The synthesized Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4 and 0.35) oxides catalysts displayed excellent SCR activity, N2 selectivity and SO2/H2O resistance. The structure, redox ability and reactivity of NH3 and absorbed NO species on the catalyst were explored by using various characterization techniques. The characterization results point out that the introduction of Nb to Fe0.5-Ce0.5 oxides significantly enhances the surface area, redox ability, acidity and reactivity of NH3 together with absorbed nitrate. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals The reagents were purchased from different companies and were used without any further purification. The iron nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O) were purchased from Tianjin Tianli Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd, cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O) were purchased from Tianjin Guangfu Fine Chemical Research Institute, niobium chloride (NbCl5) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial corporation and citric acid monohydrate (C6H8O7·H2O) were purchased from Tianjin Fuchen Chemical Reagent Factory. 2.2 Preparation of Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) oxides The oxides catalysts with different amount of Fe, Ce and Nb were prepared by citric acid method. Briefly, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.35–0.5 mol), NbCl5 (0.05–0.15 mol), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (0.5 mol) and citric acid (0.05 mol) were added into distilled water (50 mL), and stirred at 50 °C until the complete dissolution of solids. In the catalyst synthesis, the molar ratio of citric acid to the total metal component (the sum of Fe, Nb, and Ce) was kept 1:0.05. After complete dissolution of salt, the resultant solution was heated at 140 °C for 8 h, and consequently porous foam like solid materials were obtained. The porous foam solid material were crushed into powder, and calcined in air muffle furnace at 500 °C for 5 h to obtain the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 oxides catalysts, in which x is 0.45, 0.40 and 0.35 based on the molar composition of Fe, Nb and Ce in the catalysts. According to the above method, the Fe0.5-Ce0.5 oxides, Nb0.5-Ce0.5 oxides and Nb2O5 were also prepared as reference materials. 2.3 Characterizations of Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) oxides The powdered X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments were performed on a Brucker D8 Advance X-rays diffractometer. The instrument was equipped with a radiation source of Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å), and the X-rays tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The X-rays diffractogram was assembled in the 2θ scanning range of 20–80 with step of 0.02. The BET surface area of the samples was investigated through Micrometric Tristar II analyzer at low temperature (liquid N2 at −196 °C). Temperature program reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) was tested with AutoChem TP5080 chemisorptions analyzer (Xianquan Tianjin, china). 0.020 g of the catalyst was pretreated in the flow of O2 (25 mL/min) for 1 h at 300 °C, and in the same O2 flow the sample was cooled down. In the final step, the temperature was increased from room temperature to 900 °C at heating rate of 10 °C/min in a flow of 5% H2/N2 (30 mL/min), and the corresponding data was recorded continuously. The temperature program desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) and temperature program desorption of NO (NO-TPD) measurements were performed by using AutoChem TP5080 chemisorptions analyzer (Xianquan Tianjin china). To detect the signal of NH3 (m/z = 17), NO (m/z = 17), N2O (m/z = 44), NO2 (m/z = 46), and O2 (m/z = 32) species, TCD and mass spectra (QIC-20 Hidden) were used. In the first step, 0.100 g of the sample was pretreated in helium flow for 1 h at 300 °C, and in the same flow the sample was cooled down to room temperature. After that anhydrous NH3/NO (flow rate 30 mL/min) was introduced for 1 h, followed by Helium (30 mL/min) purging at the same temperature for 1 h to avoid the physisorption of NH3/or NO. In the final step, the saturated sample with NH3/NO was heated under Helium flow (30 mL/min) to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement was carried out through Kratos-AXIS ULTRA OLD equipped with an Al K α radiation source. Binding energy (BE) was calibrated using the C 1s peak (BE = 284.7 eV) as an internal standard. The in situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) tests were conducted by a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer, containing in situ diffuse reflectance cell (Harrick) and high sensitivity MCT detector which was cooled by liquid N2. The sample was loaded in the Harrick IR cell and heated to 350 °C for 30 min to remove adsorbed impurities in N2 flow (200 mL min−1). The background spectrum was recorded after the sample was cooled down to the desired reaction temperature. In the DRIFTS experiments, the spectra were recorded by accumulating 64 scans with 4 cm−1 resolution. The testing conditions were as follow: NH3 (1000 ppm), NO (1000 ppm), O2 (3% if used) with N2 balance, while the total rate of the feed gas was maintained 200 mL/min. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurement The SCR activity test for all synthesized sample was carried out through fixed bed quartz reactor with inner diameter of 6 mm. The reaction conditions were controlled as follow: NH3 (1000 ppm), NO (1000 ppm), O2 (3% if used) with N2 balance, while the sum of all gas flow rate was 200 mL/min, and the corresponding gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 35,000 h−1. In the experiment, 0.400 g of samples (40–60 mesh) were used. The catalytic activity of the samples were carried out in temperature range of 90–450 °C, and online mass spectra (QIC 20, Hiden) was applied to analyze the concentration of NO, NO2, N2O and NH3 by the corresponding standard curves. The data was recorded at each temperature after at least 40 min. NO conversion, NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated based on the following Eqs. (1)–(3), respectively [38]. (1) NO conversion ( % ) = [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out [ NO ] in × 100 (2) NH 3 conversion ( % ) = [ NH 3 ] in − [ NH 3 ] out [ NH 3 ] in × 100 (3) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = [ NO ] in + [ NH 3 ] in − [ NO 2 ] out − 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ NO ] in + [ NH 3 ] in × 100 In the above three equations, [NO]in, [NH3]in [NO]out, [NH3]out, [NO2]out and [N2O]out represent the inlet and outlet amounts of NO, NH3, NO, NH3, NO2 and N2O, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity for NH3-SCR The NO conversion over Fe0.5-Ce0.5, Nb0.5-Ce0.5, pure Nb2O5 and Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) was evaluated in broad temperature of 90 °C to 420 °C, and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. 1 (A). The Fe0.5-Ce0.5 catalyst displayed the best NO conversion in the range of 270–330 °C, while the NO conversion was only about 48% at low temperature (150 °C). The Nb0.5-Ce0.5 oxides catalyst exhibited the best NO conversion in the range of 270–360 °C, while the NO conversion was only about 43% at 180 °C (Fig. S1). Similarly, pure Nb2O5 sample showed less than 20% NO conversion in the whole reaction process. Interestingly, the Nb containing catalysts (Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35)) displayed outstanding NH3- SCR of NO activity both at lower and higher temperature. The small amount of Nb had no prominent effect, as in the case of Fe0.45-Nb0.05-Ce0.5 catalyst only gave 100% NO conversion in the reaction window of 240–360 °C. On further increasing the Nb amount leaded to a great improvement of SCR activity at both low and high temperature. The Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst exhibited 70% NO conversion from 150 °C to 420 °C, and 100% NO conversion in the range of 210–390 °C, which was an excellent low temperature SCR catalyst with so wide activity window of 180–400 °C (>90% NO conversion). However, further increasing the Nb amount to 0.15, it was found that the SCR activity decreased at low temperature as in the case of the Fe0.35-Nb0.15-Ce0.5 catalyst which showed 64% NO conversion at 150 °C. These results indicate that the addition of Nb plays an important role in the high NH3-SCR performance over the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 oxides catalysts. The introduction of Nb also promoted the N2 selectivity of the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) catalysts as depicted in Fig. 1(B). The Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and pure Nb2O5 samples showed much lower N2 selectivity and start to decline at 330 and 300 °C, respectively. For the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) catalysts, they displayed good selectivity to N2 during the whole reaction temperature window. Among these catalysts, the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst showed much better selectivity to N2 (more than 95%) in the whole temperature range. In addition, the NH3 conversion over the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) was also tested as shown in Fig. 1(C). Below 330 °C, the conversion of NH3 over each Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 catalyst was almost same as that of NO at each temperature, demonstrating that same molar ratio of both species (NO and NH3) were consumed. Moreover, it was noted that the NH3 conversion over the Fe0.5-Ce0.5 catalyst increased to 100% above 270 °C, consequently the quickly decrease in the NO conversion, which is related to the over oxidation of NH3 in SCR reaction. 3.2 Effect of SO2 and H2O In the NH3-SCR reaction, the SO2 and H2O are considered as main deactivating species [1]. Therefore, much better SO2 and H2O durability of catalyst is required for NH3-SCR. To explore the H2O and SO2 durability of the synthesized catalyst, Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst was chosen for the experiments due to its excellent activity and the results are displayed in Fig. 2 (A). The SO2 and H2O durability test was carried out at 220 °C and before the addition of SO2 to the feed, the reaction was operated for 6 h. NO conversion still remained 100% after adding 100 ppm SO2 in the feed, and maintained at steady value even the amount of SO2 was increased to 200 ppm. These results points out that the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst displays good resistance to SO2, which is considered as important property for industrial use. The addition of 6% H2O in the gas stream without SO2 did not affect the NO conversion, suggesting the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst has also good water resistance. Further increasing the H2O amount from 6% to 12%, the conversion of NO dropped to 90%, and restored to 100% when the H2O supply was removed. The results indicate that the presence of 12% H2O shows restrain to the SCR reaction in some extent. To study the combined influence of SO2 and H2O on the activity, SO2 (100 ppm) and H2O (12%) were added to the gas stream for 8 h simultaneously. It was noteworthy that NO conversion dropped to about 90%, and restored to nearly 100% after removing the supply of H2O and SO2 supply. These results reveal that H2O and SO2 had a negligible influence on the SCR activity. Thus, the above results reveal that the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst demonstrates outstanding NH3-SCR of NO performance even in the feed containing H2O and SO2. The SO2 durability test was also performed in the presence of higher concentration of SO2 (300 ppm). As displayed in Fig. S2, when 300 ppm SO2 was added to the feed, the NO conversion remained 100% for the first 2 h, and then decreased to 85% after 6 h and remained in steady state after 8 h. The NO conversion activity restored to 100% when the SO2 supply was removed. These results indicate that the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst has excellent SO2 tolerance, which is very important for the industrial application. In addition, the investigation of H2O effect on NH3-SCR of NO reaction over the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst was carried out in presence of 5% H2O in the testing temperature window of 120–420 °C. As shown in Fig. 2(B), when 5% H2O was introduced into the reaction atmosphere, the NO conversion exhibited a slight decline at lower temperature, while it was not influenced at higher temperature. It was worth mentioning that the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst displayed over 90% NO conversion in a broad reaction window of 210–390 °C even in the presence of 5% H2O. The time on steam experiment was also performed for 35 h in the presence of 6% H2O presented in Fig. S3. The reaction was operated for 4 h before the addition of H2O. When 6% H2O was added to the NO conversion decreased to 93% and remains in the steady state even after 33 h, and restored to 100% after the H2O supply was turned off. The results indicate that the presence of 6% H2O shows restrain to the SCR reaction in some extent. Hence, the above results reveal that the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst is best choice for NH3-SCR of NO reaction. 3.3 NO and NH3 separate oxidation To examine the redox ability of Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35), the oxidation of separated NO and NH3 was carried out over the Fe0.5-Ce0.5, Nb2O5 and Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) catalysts. Generally, the NO oxidation to NO2 is significant for low-temperature SCR, because it accelerate the (fast SCR) reaction (2NH3 + NO + NO2 → 2N2 + 3H2O), and consequently enhance the DeNOx efficiency [11,39,40]. As depicted in Fig. S4(A) (Supplementary Information), the NO2 concentration over the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) samples was high slightly as compared to Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and Nb2O5. These results indicate that the addition of Nb to Fe0.5-Ce0.5 could successfully improve the NO oxidation during NH3-SCR process and subsequently enhance the NH3-SCR activity at lower temperature. The experimental results of the separated NH3 oxidation were shown in Fig. S4(B) (Supplementary Information) over the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 catalysts. It can be observed that the NH3 conversion of the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) catalysts was also higher than that of Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and Nb2O5. These results point out that the Nb addition to Fe0.5-Ce0.5 promotes the NH3 activation and redox property of catalyst, and thus it is significant for NH3-SCR activity. Nevertheless, below 250 °C the conversion of NH3 was almost 50% over Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) catalyst. Moreover, it is worth mentioning that the conversion of NH3 improved tremendously and reached to 100% at 300 °C, which suggests that the suitable redox ability is advantage of the N2 selectivity for NH3-SCR reaction at low temperature due to the over-oxidation of NH3 at high temperature. 3.4 Texture property The XRD results of these catalysts are summarized in Fig. 3 . The XRD pattern of Fe2O3 (JCPDS 33-0664) was given for comparison [25]. The characteristic diffraction peaks of CeO2 (JCPDS 43-0394) [9] were detected for the Fe0.5-Ce0.5 catalyst. For the Nb2O5 sample, the measured diffraction peaks were belong to Nb2O5 phase (JCPDS 28-0317) [9]. In case of Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35), very fascinating diffraction patterns were observed. The diffraction peaks attributed to the Nb2O5 phase and Fe2O3 phase were not observed, while the diffraction peaks of CeO2 were detected in all samples. These results demonstrate that highly dispersed Fe and Nb oxides were formed in the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 catalysts, which should be attributed to the strong interaction among Nb, Fe and Ce oxides. The BET surface areas of all catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . The BET surface area of the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) catalysts was noticeably higher than that of Nb2O5 (24 m2 g−1) and Fe0.5-Ce0.5 (23 m2 g−1). Among the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) catalysts, the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst presented the highest value (61 m2 g−1). Therefore, it could make available more active and absorption sites, and consequently enhances the NH3-SCR of NO activity of the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst. 3.5 H2-TPR study H2-TPR experiments were performed to explore the influence of the Nb content on the reducibility of the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 catalysts as shown in Fig. 4 . The pure Nb2O5 gave a single peak at 851 °C which was attributed to the reduction of bulk niobium oxide [41]. The TPR profile of Fe0.5-Ce0.5 catalyst displayed two broad peaks and one very weak peak. The first broad peak in the range of 300–500 °C was ascribed to the reduction of Fe2O3–Fe3O4 [42,43]. The other broad peak in the range of 500–630 °C was overlapped peak, and can be attributed to the reduction of surface CeO2, Fe3O4 to FeO and Fe simultaneously [42,43]. The weak peak at 763 °C can be attributed to the reduction of bulk CeO2 [37,38]. When small amount of Nb was added to Fe0.5-Ce0.5, the corresponding reduction peaks below 500 °C became broad and slightly shifted to lower temperature. Besides, a broad overlapped peak was observed in the range of 500–750 °C, which can be assigned to the multi-stage reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO and Fe, bulk CeO2 and niobium oxide [41–43]. The above results indicate the strong interaction exists among Nb, Fe and Ce oxides, which increase the redox property of the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 catalysts. The H2 consumption was calculated and the results are shown in Table 1. Moreover, the H2 consumption of Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) is higher than that of Fe0.5-Ce0.5, suggesting that the redox property of Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 is improved after the introduction of Nb to Fe0.5-Ce0.5 catalyst, which is responsible for the excellent NH3-SCR performance at low temperature. 3.6 NH3-TPD analysis The acidity plays very important role in the NH3-SCR reaction. The NH3-TPD was performed to explore the adsorption and activation of NH3 on the catalyst surface. The NH3-TPD results of the Nb2O5, Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 5 (A). Each catalyst exhibited a wide desorption peak at 105 °C, and a weak peak at 420 °C. Normally, the peak observed at lower temperature are attributed to the desorption of NH3 bonded to weak acid sites, while the peak in the range of 300–500 °C are attributed to the desorption of NH3 bonded to the medium acid sites [44,45]. From desorption peak area the acid amount of the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 catalysts were calculated. The acid amount is 24, 21, 33 and 27 μmol g−1 for Fe0.5-Ce0.5, Fe0.45-Nb0.05-Ce0.5, Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 and Fe0.35-Nb0.15-Ce0.5, respectively. The NH3-TPD results illustrate Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 has the largest NH3 storage capacity. These results bring out that the addition of suitable Nb can significantly enhance the acidity. Hence, it is concluded that more ammonia species on the surface of the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst can involve in the SCR process, which could significantly enhance the NH3-SCR of NO activity. 3.7 NO-TPD results The NO-TPD profiles of Nb2O5, Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) are illustrated in Fig. 5(B). It can be noticed that there were two groups of desorption peaks for all catalysts. In the NO-TPD experiment, normally the peak located at lower temperature (below 250 °C) can be attributed to the desorption of monodentate nitrate and weakly adsorb NO species [13,34], while the peak observed at higher temperature (above 250 °C) are ascribed to the decomposition of bidentate nitrate and bridging nitrate species [13,34]. The Nb2O5 sample showed a broad peak at about 350 °C, and for Fe0.5-Ce0.5 sample, a strong peak below 195 °C and a weak wide peak at 350 °C were observed. In case of Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35), two obvious peaks at 50–250 °C and 300–450 °C were also detected. However, compared the area of the desorption peaks, it can be found that the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 exhibited the largest peak area both at low and high temperature among these catalysts, indicating that it has the highest NO adsorption capacity. The above results reveal that the addition of Nb can significantly improve the NO adsorption capacity of Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5, which was beneficial for its excellent SCR performance. 3.8 XPS study The XPS study was carried out to explore the specific surface oxidation state and surface atomic concentrations of iron, cerium, niobium and oxygen for different catalysts. To investigate the surface composition and their relative atomic concentration in different catalyst, the Fe2p3/2, Ce3d, Nb3d and O1s XPS were deconvoluted into various peaks as shown in (Fig. 6 ). The relative atomic concentration was calculated from the peak area summarized in Table 1. In Fig. 6(A), the deconvoluted XPS spectra of Fe2p for different catalyst are shown. The characteristic bands of Fe2p1/2 and Fe2p3/2 located at 724 and 711 eV, respectively. The Fe 2p3/2 peak was further deconvoluted into two distinct bands by the same peak fitting deconvolution technique. The band centered at 710.8 eV can be attributed to FeO and the band centered at 713.5 can be assigned to Fe2O3 [46]. It is deduced from the above results that the iron species in our samples presents as both Fe2+ and Fe3+. From the peak area, the relative Fe3+ percentage to total Fe species (Fe2+ + Fe3+) was calculated (Fe3+/(Fe2+ + Fe3+)). As summarized in Table 1, with introduction of Nb, the surface Fe3+ content gradually increased from 55% for Fe0.5-Ce0.5 to the maximum 62% for Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5, then reduced to 58% for Fe0.35-Nb0.15-Ce0.5. According to previous literatures [47,48], the Fe3+ species facilitated the SCR of NO activity at low temperature. Thus, it may be one of the possible reasons that the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst exhibits good low-temperature SCR activity. The complex spectrum of Ce3d was deconvoluted into ten peaks and the corresponding results are given in Fig. 6(B). The deconvoluted peaks were labeled as U0 (899.6 eV), U (901.3 eV), U′ (904.6 eV), U″ (907.8 eV) U‴ (915.0 eV), V0 (881.7 eV), V (884.5 eV), V' (887.7 eV), V″ (890.5 eV) and V‴ (897.1 eV). The deconvlouted peaks labeled as “U” symbolize the Ce3d3/2 spin-orbit components, and those donated as “V” symbolize the Ce3d5/2 spin-orbit components [49,50]. In the previous works, the peak labeled as Vo, V′, Uo, and U′ were assigned to the Ce3+ species, and the peaks donated as V, V″, V‴, U,U″, and U‴ belonged to the Ce4+ species [51–54]. The XPS of Ce3d reveals that both Ce3+ and Ce4+ species coexisted on the surface of all samples. The relative percentage of Ce3+ to total cerium species (Ce3+/(Ce4+ + Ce3+)) in all synthesized catalyst was obtained from the area ratio (Table 1). The Ce3+/(Ce4+ + Ce3+) ratio of Fe0.5-Ce0.5 was 42%, but it increased for Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35). Meanwhile, Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 has the highest the Ce3+/(Ce4+ + Ce3+) ratio (47%). It demonstrates that the addition of Nb greatly transforms the Ce4+ to Ce3+ on the surface of Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) compared to Fe0.5-Ce0.5. Nb3d spectra are presented in Fig. 6(C). According to literatures [55–57], the binding energy of Nb3d5/2 at about 206.8 and 205.6 eV could be ascribed to the Nb5+ and Nb4+ species, respectively. The corresponding relative percentage of niobium species in all synthesized catalyst was calculated based on the area ratio of Nb5+ to (Nb5+ + Nb4+) (Nb5+/(Nb5+ + Nb4+)) listed in Table 1. The Nb5+/(Nb5+ + Nb4+) ratio of the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) catalysts is higher than pure Nb2O5 sample. It is interesting that the variation tendency for the relative content of the surface Fe3+ and Ce3+ species is almost same as the value of x in Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) displayed in Fig. 7 . Thus, we put forward to that there was the reaction Ce4+ + Fe2+ ↔ Ce3+ + Fe3+ due to the electronic transfer between Ce4+ and Fe2+. In addition, it was found that the variation of the surface Nb5+ amount is similar to that of the Ce3+ species (Fig. 7), which may be have the possible reaction between Ce4+ and Nb4+ as follows: Ce4+ + Nb4+ ↔ Ce3+ + Nb5+. The XPS spectra of O1 s were fitted into two peaks as depicted in Fig. 6(D). The O1s peaks observed at 530.4–531.1 eV was assigned to chemisorbed oxygen species O2 δ− including O− and O2 − (donated as Oα) and the binding energy at 529.6–529.8 eV was attributed to the lattice oxygen species O2− (denoted as Oβ) [32,58]. Table 1 summarizes the relative amount ratio of Oα to (Oα + Oβ) (Oα/(Oα + Oβ)) over these catalysts. The values are 51%, 53%, 59%, 55% and 50% for Fe0.5-Ce0.5, Fe 0.45-Nb0.05-Ce0.5, Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5, Fe0.35-Nb0.15-Ce0.5 and Nb2O5, respectively. Obviously, the (Oα/Oα + Oβ) ratio of Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) is higher than that of Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and Nb2O5. Moreover, the relative concentration Oα/(Oα + Oβ) ratio of Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 is the highest among Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35), suggesting that Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 possesses the most content of the surface chemisorbed oxygen species, which is favor of NO oxidation to NO2. This result is consistent with the oxidation of NO depicted in Fig. S4(A) (Supplementary Information). The more the chemisorbed oxygen species is on its surface, the better activity at low temperature it is due to the quick NH3-SCR reaction (Fig. 1). 3.9 In situ DRIFTS study 3.9.1 Separate adsorption of NH3 and NO + O2 NH3 adsorption on the Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalysts with the time was examined by in situ DRIFTS, and the corresponding results are depicted in Fig. S5 (Supplementary Information). In the range of 960–1750 and 3100–3700 cm−1 several bands were observed for the Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalysts. The bands at 1608–1603 cm−1 and strong bands in the range of 1166–1236 cm−1 were ascribed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching mode of NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites, respectively [59–62]. The bands located at 1421 and 1703–1715 cm−1 were respectively ascribed to the σas and σs of NH4 + adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites [63]. Several peaks were observed at 3360, 3245 and 3140 cm−1 in the N-H region that belonged to the coordinated NH3 on the Lewis acid sites [59–62]. In addition, a negative peak detected at 3650 cm−1 could be attributed to the stretching vibration of OH group occupied by the absorbed NH3 [63,64]. Two peak at (1576–1570 and 1321 cm−1) were assigned to the amide (NH2) species [61,65] originated from the deprotonation of ammonia via partial oxidation. In case of the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst, a negative peak observed at 960 cm−1 was ascribed to the NbO stretching mode, which points out that during the NH3 absorption the NbO was consumed. [55]. The consumption of NbO and NbOH demonstrate that during the NH3 absorption both of NbOH [55] and NbO [34] could act as Brønsted and Lewis acid sites over Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5, respectively [34,55]. It was noteworthy that the adsorption bands of the NH3 species on the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst were much more intense than those on the Fe0.5-Ce0.5 catalyst, indicating that Nb addition improves the amounts of both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. In addition, the NH3-TPD results also indicate that the total amount of NH3 adsorbed on Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 was higher than that on the Fe0.5-Ce0.5 catalyst. The NO + O2 adsorption on Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 with time was also investigated by DRIFTS (Fig. S6 in Supplementary Information). Bands at 1602, 1570–1575, 1541, 1231–1238, 1263–1270 and 1194–1216 cm−1 were observed for both Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalysts. The bands at 1570–1575, 1231–1238 and 1194–1216 cm−1 were the bridging nitrate and bidentate nitrate species [59–61], while the bands at 1263–1270 and 1541 cm−1 were the monodentate nitrate species [66,67]. Similarly, the bands at 1602 cm−1 belonged to the absorbed NO2 species [68,69]. The band at 1012 cm−1 detected on both catalysts was assigned to bidentate nitrate [33]. In case of Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5, two weak bands at 1339 and 1375 cm−1 were the cis-N2O2 species [70]. The introduction of Nb significantly enhances the bands due to adsorbed nitrate species. It is obviously observed that the bands intensities of the gaseous NO2 and monodentate nitrate over Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 are much higher than those over Fe0.5-Ce0.5, thus, the two species are considered to be the reactive species in the NH3-SCR of NO reaction [13]. According to literature study [71], the NO2 was also thought to be a key intermediate in the low temperature SCR reaction. Furthermore, it is concluded that the Nb addition improves the formation of active sites for the nitrate adsorbed, which could also be confirmed by the results drawn from NO-TPD in Fig. 5(B). 3.9.2 Reaction between absorbed NH3 and NO + O2 Reaction between absorbed NH3 and NO + O2 at 200 °C is depicted in Fig. 8 . In the first step of this experiment, the sample was purged with NH3, in the next step the sample was purged with N2 for 30 min. Finally, NO+O2 was added to gas stream and the corresponding spectra was recorded with different time. The NH3 coordinated peaks (1612–1614 and bands in the range of 1177–1234 cm−1) [32,59,60], coordinated NH4 + (1712–1714 cm−1) [63], and numerous peaks of NH (3360, 3245 and 3156 cm−1) [32,59,60] were observed on Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalysts upon treatment with NH3. In the IR cell when NO+O2 was introduced, all bands of ammonia species disappeared quickly, with the appearance of new characteristic peaks of bidentate and bridged nitrate (1570, 1215–1220 cm−1) [59,60], monodentate nitrates (1541–1548 cm−1) [66,67] and absorbed NO2 species (1602–1604 cm−1) [68,69]. However, the characteristic peaks of the coordinated NH3 disappeared after NO + O2 was introduced into the IR cell for 5 min over the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst, while the corresponding bands were still prominent over the Fe0.5-Ce0.5 catalyst. The above results indicate that the addition of Nb accelerate the reaction between surface NO and the adsorbed NH3 species. 3.9.3 Reaction between ammonia and adsorbed nitrogen oxides species In the first step of this experiment, the sample was purged with NO + O2, in the next step the sample was purged with N2 for 30 min. Finally, NH3 was added to gas stream and the corresponding spectra was recorded with different time. The results are displayed in Fig. 9 . When the NO + O2 pretreated catalyst was exposed to the NH3, the decrease in intensity of NO2 bands at 1602 cm−1 was observed, and the band at 1545 cm−1 shifted to 1523 cm−1, which can be attributed to the deformation of the nitrate species [54]. Meanwhile, the bands in the range of 1712–1714 cm−1 belonged to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching mode of NH4 + species bonded to the Brønsted acid sites [63], and numerous peaks at 1608, 3360, 3246 and 3156 cm−1 ascribed to NH3 coordinated Lewis acid sites [60–62] were observed. After the catalyst was exposed to NH3 for 30 min, both adsorbed NH3 and adsorbed NO x species could be observed on the surface of catalyst. Thus, it can be concluded from the above results that at low temperature the absorbed NO2 species (1603 cm−1) [68,69], and bridged nitrate (1215 cm−1) [59,60] were highly reactive species. In contrast, the bands attributed to bidentate (1570 cm−1) [59,60] and deformation of nitrate species (1523 cm−1) [54] were observed even after 30 min, confirming that these species were inactive during the reaction. Furthermore, the coexistence of NH3 and adsorbed NO x species on catalyst surface demonstrated that NH3 and NO x could be adsorbed on different active sites [32]. 3.9.4 Co-adsorption of NO + O2 + NH3 The DRIFTS of co-adsorption of NO + O2 + NH3 are depicted in Fig. 10 over Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 at different temperatures. For both catalysts below 300 °C, numerous bands coordinated NH3 on the Lewis acid sites (3356, 3245–3256 and 3140–3152 cm−1) in the N-H region were observed [59–61]. The bands at 1705–1715 cm−1 attributed to the σs and σas of NH4 + on the Brønsted acid sites [63]. The Band at 1230–1194 cm−1 can be ascribed to overlapping of coordinated NH3 and bridging nitrate. The band at 1605–1603 cm−1 might belong to the overlapping of bands of NH3 and coordinated NO2. The bidentate and deformation of nitrate species appeared at 1570 and 1518 cm−1, respectively [59–61]. In case of Fe0.5-Ce0.5, NH3 related bands diminish with increasing the temperature, while the nitrate related bands increase in intensity and persistent even at 350 °C. These results indicate that the surface of the Fe0.5-Ce0.5 catalyst is dominantly covered with nitrates, and consequently the nitrates species is difficult to react with ammonia that is not an inactive in the NH3-SCR reaction over the Fe0.5-Ce0.5 catalyst. On the other hand, the nitrates species on the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst decrease in intensity with the increase in temperature and no bands were observed at 350 °C. These results points out that the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst shows much better NH3-SCR activity than Fe0.5-Ce0.5. The above results point out that most of the NO x species react with absorbed NH3 species and consumed. When the temperature increased, the band intensity of the coordinated NH3 on the Lewis acid sites did not changed at low temperature, while the bands intensity of NH4 + on the Bronsted acid sites decreased. Thus, it can be summarized that the NH4 + species bonded to the Bronsted acid sites is more active at low temperature (<200 °C) than the coordinated NH3 on the Lewis acid sites, while on other hand at high temperature (>200 °C), the coordinated NH3 on the Lewis acid sites also take part in the NH3-SCR reaction. For the NH3-SCR reaction, the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) and Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanisms are commonly proposed at low and high temperature, respectively [54,61,72]. Generally, the adsorption of NH3 is regarded as the initial step [33]. A simplified reaction mechanism over Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst was proposed. From the NH3 + NO + O2 co-adsorption experiment, it is evident that both adsorbed NO x and NH3 species are considered to be participate in the SCR reaction below 200 °C (Fig. 10). In addition, the coordinated NH3 and ionic NH4 + could participate in reaction with nitrate species (Fig. 8). The in situ formed NO2 was most commonly regarded as key intermediates in the low-temperature SCR reaction [73,74], and it was confirmed by the study of NO2 in Fig. 9. Hence, it is concluded that at low temperature (<200 °C), coordinated NH3, ionic NH4 + and in situ formed NO2 species are suggested to be active species and participate in the NH3-SCR reaction following the “LH” route. The above mentioned results demonstrate that the adsorbed NO x species could be formed on Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 at high temperature. However, in light of NH3 + NO + O2 co-adsorption experiment, the catalyst surface was mainly covered by adsorbed NH3 species (shown in Fig. 10) which could be attributed to the fast reaction between weakly adsorbed NO and adsorbed NH3 species. As presented in Fig. 10, the bands ascribed to the coordinated NH3 (1208 cm−1) appeared and remained unchanged with increasing temperature (<200 °C). This absorbed NH3 first through oxidative dehydrogenation transformed to NH2 species, and then reacts with NO to form unstable NH2NO intermediate species [33]. The NH2NO intermediate species is quite unstable species and quickly decompose into N2 and H2O [33,75]. However, under the SCR condition the band of NH2NO species was not detected on the catalyst surface due to its repaid decomposition[75]. In this way, at high temperature (>200 °C), the absorb NO and NH2 react with weakly adsorbed NO or gas-phase and follow an E-R mechanism. 3.10 Promotional effects of Nb on Fe0.5-Ce0.5 The addition of niobium can enhance the low-temperature NH3-SCR activity, N2 selectivity and SO2/H2O durability of Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5, (x = 0.5, 0.45, 0.4, 0.35). Among all the synthesized catalysts, the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst showed 100% NO conversion and 95% N2 selectivity in the range of 210–390 °C. The detail of Nb promotional effect can be explained as follows. From the above results, it is concluded that the introduction of Nb into Fe0.5-Ce0.5 could bring modification in the samples structure and lead to the change of surface area, structure and surface property. Meanwhile, Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 offered the largest BET surface (61 m2 g−1) due to its amorphous structure confirmed by XRD (Fig. 3), which could make available more active and absorption sites, and as a result contributed to the outstanding NH3-SCR reaction to some extent [76]. The XRD results point out that there is strong interaction of Nb with Fe and Ce oxides. In addition, H2-TPR results (Fig. 4) suggest that the redox properties were enhanced after Nb addition derived from the strong interaction among Nb, Fe and Ce oxides. The above redox feature is responsible for the excellent SCR activity. The strong interaction also enhances the mobility of surface oxygen, and therefore more chemisorbed oxygen species are formed on the catalyst surface, from the XPS results it is further conformed (Table 1). The Oα/(Oα + Oβ) ratio of the Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5, (x = 0.5, 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) catalysts is higher than Fe0.5-Ce0.5 and Nb2O5, meanwhile, the Oα/(Oα + Oβ) ratio of Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 is higher than that of the other Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 catalysts. The XPS results indicate the addition of Nb cause multiple redox reactions (Ce4+ + Nb4+ ↔ Ce3+ + Nb5+, and Fe2+ + Nb5+ ↔ Fe3+ + Nb4+). The reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ can produce oxygen vacancy, unsaturated chemical bond and charge imbalance on catalysts surface [77], which is significant for the activation and absorption of the reactants in the NH3-SCR reaction. Similarly, the Fe3+ sites facilitate the SCR of NO at low temperature. Thus, the result may be one of the possible reasons that the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst exhibits good low-temperature SCR activity. Furthermore, the NH3-TPD and NO-TPD results (Fig. 5) suggest that Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5, (x = 0.5, 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) possess more acid amounts and NO adsorption sites, that play important role in enhancing activity of the NH3-SCR reaction. The larger amounts of acid site on the surface of a catalyst can provide more amounts of the adsorbed NH3 species to the SCR process, and consequently promoting the NH3-SCR of NO activity. The NO-TPD results suggest that the addition of Nb significantly improves the NO adsorption capacity of resultant catalyst, which was also significant for the NH3-SCR of NO activity. The Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst exhibits the most acidic sites and the highest NO adsorption capacity among theses Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 catalysts, which may be responsible for its outstanding NH3-SCR of NO activity and N2 selectivity. Furthermore, the addition of Nb considerably enhances the amount and strength of both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, especially the Brønsted acid from the in situ DRIFTS results. According to the literatures [78–80], both Brønsted acid and Lewis acid are useful for the selectivity to N2 at high temperature. Additionally, the in-situ DRIFTS studies point out that both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites can participate in the SCR reactions. But it is observed that the bands intensity of the NH4 + species on the Bronsted acid sites decreases much more rapidly than that of the Lewis acid sites when the adsorbed NH3 species reacts with NOx, which demonstrates that the Bronsted acid sites over Fe 0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 were much more active than the Lewis acid sites at low temperature. In general, the Nb addition plays an important role in its high low-temperature activity by the interaction among Nb, Fe and Ce oxides. 4 Conclusion A series of Nb-promoted Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) oxides was synthesized and applied in the NH3-SCR reaction. The Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst showed outstanding NH3-SCR activity in broad temperature window from 180 °C to 400 °C (>90% NO conversion), together with excellent N2 selectivity and remarkable SO2/H2O resistance. Due to strong interaction among Nb, Fe and cerium oxides, the redox property of the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst is promoted, which is responsible for its outstanding NH3-SCR activity. The addition of Nb causes dual redox reactions, Ce4+ + Nb4+ ↔ Ce3+ + Nb5+ and Fe2+ + Nb5+ ↔ Fe3+ + Nb4+, which are responsible for creating the more oxygen vacancy, unsaturated chemical bond, and charge imbalance on the surface of the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst compared with the other catalysts. Furthermore, the Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 catalyst has the most acid amount and NO adsorption capacity, which is also significant for the NH3-SCR of NO activity. coredata.dc:description: Citric acid method was employed to prepare a series of Nb-promoted Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) oxides for selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) of NO process. The structure, redox ability and reactivity of NH3 and absorbed NO species on the catalysts were explored by using various characterization techniques such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature program reduction with H2 (H2-TPR), temperature program desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD), temperature program desorption of NO (NO-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and in situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS). It was found that the Nb promoted Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) oxides catalysts showed outstanding NH3-SCR of NO activity, excellent N2 selectivity and remarkable SO2/H2O resistance, meanwhile, Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 exhibited above 90% NO conversion in the range of 180–400 °C, together with near 100% N2 selectivity. The characterization results point out that the excellent catalytic performance of Fe0.4-Nb0.1-Ce0.5 can be ascribed to the strong interaction among Nb, Fe and Ce oxides. The strong interaction not only increases the BET surface area and redox ability of the catalyst, but also significantly improves the acid amount leading to the enhancement of the adsorption and activation of NH3, which is advantage of the reactivity of adsorbed nitrate together with the adsorbed NH3 species.
coredata.dc:title: Promotional effects of Nb on selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 over Fe x -Nb0.5-x -Ce0.5 (x = 0.45, 0.4, 0.35) oxides catalysts
